Award.AwardTitle: Student training in linguistics and cultural anthropology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to support graduate student travel to an interdisciplinary international conference on language and gender; it provides support for graduate student travel to the upcoming meeting of the International Gender and Language Association (IGALA) in Gaborone, Botswana in June 2018. Participation in this conference will enable graduate students to present their original research, receive feedback on their work from senior scholars in their field, attend papers, panels and keynote lectures on a variety of topics by a diverse, international group of researchers, and build professional connections by networking with fellow researchers of gender, sexuality, and language, particularly those from southern Africa, where the conference will be held. The conference theme of Gender and Language in Multicultural Contexts, and given the conference location, we expect southern Africa to be especially well-represented in terms of paper topics and participants. The travel awards will be used to encourage the participation of US-based graduate students despite the high cost of travel to the conference site, and they will particularly aim to ensure the participation of scholars from underrepresented minority groups. As has been reported by recipients of previous funding, travel to international conferences would have been out of reach financially without support, and these opportunities enabled participants to initiate research collaborations, make contacts crucial to their successful completion of fieldwork, and disseminate their research in scholarly outlets.

IGALA is the world's largest and most prestigious conference on language and gender; attendees have come from North and South America, Europe, Africa, the Middle East, Asia and the Pacific Islands, Australia and New Zealand. The association's most recent meeting - IGALA 9 in 2016 in Hong Kong - attracted a total attendance of well over 200 people and featured more than 150 papers by 105 faculty and 85 students. At least fifteen of those students were from the US, thanks to funding support from NSF. The upcoming meeting has the potential to maintain that number of US-based graduate student researchers with support. IGALA conferences consistently draws the most prominent figures in the field in disciplines including linguistics, linguistic anthropology and social psychology, and the conference welcomes both established and up-and-coming scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award of $24,000.00 provided travel grants for 15 highly qualified students based at universities in the U.S. to present their research and gain professional experience at the 10th biennial conference of the International Gender and Language Association (IGALA 10), which was held June 20-22, 2018 at the University of Botswana in Gaborone, Botswana. The International Gender and Language Association (IGALA) is the major, international scholarly organization for researchers of language, gender, and sexuality; IGALA?s biennial conference is the primary scholarly venue for research in the field. Participation in the conference was a valuable professional experience for graduate students conducting research in this area. There was an impressive, and impressively diverse, pool of over 25 graduate students eligible for the travel funding. Students were considered eligible for the funding if they had abstracts that were accepted for presentation at IGALA 10 and they were attending U.S. educational institutions, chiefly graduate programs in languages, linguistics and anthropology. 

The international conference experience at IGALA 10 not only exposed U.S.-based graduate students to international scholarship on language, gender, and sexuality, but it also allowed them to disseminate their own work to a broad, international audience. The 10th biennial meeting of the conference was the first time that IGALA had met in Africa, where, according to local organizers, research on language, gender, and sexuality is still in its infancy. By sharing their work at IGALA 10, U.S. graduate student scholars were able to have an impact on the shape of the field as it develops in this region of the world. At the same time, U.S.-based graduate student researchers were able to gain important and timely insights into the relationship between language, gender, and sexuality in southern Africa through their participation in IGALA 10. The conference also included several targeted opportunities for graduate student mentoring and professional development, including panel discussions on scholarly publishing and on the job search.

Students reported that the experience was a valuable one that they would not have been able to experience were it not for the funding provided by NSF to defray the costs of the travel to an international location. They report that they were able to network with fellow graduate students from across the U.S. and around the world, connect with scholars from southern Africa whose work they had not previously been exposed to, and meet leaders in the field whose work they admired. Importantly, they were able to receive critical feedback about their research that will help them further develop their work.
